facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 952 and 953 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated July 24, 1961 of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 24, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 440 of 1953 and Civil Revision No. 1402 of 1953. B. Agarwala and K. P. Gupta, for the appellant  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment in Execution First Appeal No. 440 of 1953 and Civil Revision No. 1402 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 440 of 1953 and Civil Revision No. 1402 of 1953. B. Agarwala and K. P. Gupta, for the appellant  in both the appeals . P. Sinha and S. Shaukat Hussain, for respondent No. 1  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Appellant borrowed some money on a promissory note from the respondents predecessors.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, J. These are two companynected appeals by special leave from a companymon judgment of the Allahabad High Court. The facts necessary for present purposes may be briefly indicated. The appellant borrowed some money on a promissory numbere from the respondents predecessors.

facts.text: Suit was filed by the respondents on the basis of the promissory note.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant borrowed some money on a promissory numbere from the respondents predecessors. The suit was filed by the respondents on the basis of the promissory numbere and a decree for Rs. 2,71,000/and odd was passed against the appellant.

facts.text: Decree for Rs. 2,71,000/- and odd was passed against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed by the respondents on the basis of the promissory numbere and a decree for Rs. 2,71,000/and odd was passed against the appellant. The decree provided for 20 instalments payable half-yearly.

facts.text: Decree provided for 20 instalments payable half-yearly.

anchor.surface_text: a decree for Rs. 2,71,000/and odd was passed against the appellant. The decree provided for 20 instalments payable half-yearly. The decree also provided for one or more instalments for pendente lite and future interest beyond the twentieth instalment.

facts.text: First instalment was payable in November 1938.

anchor.surface_text: beyond the twentieth instalment. The first instalment was payable in November 1938 and thereafter each instalment was payable on or before July 31 and December 31 each year. There was also a default clause providing that in case there were three defaults in the payment of instalments, the whole decree companyld be executed.

facts.text: Each instalment payable on or before July 31 and December 31 each year.

anchor.surface_text: November 1938 and thereafter each instalment was payable on or before July 31 and December 31 each year. There was also a default clause providing that in case there were three defaults in the payment of instalments, the whole decree companyld be executed. Finally the decree created a charge on 1 8 villages belonging to the appellant.

facts.text: Default clause providing that in case of three defaults, the whole decree could be executed.

anchor.surface_text: July 31 and December 31 each year. There was also a default clause providing that in case there were three defaults in the payment of instalments, the whole decree companyld be executed. Finally the decree created a charge on 1 8 villages belonging to the appellant.

facts.text: Decree created a charge on 18 villages belonging to the appellant under s. 3 of the U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act, No. XXVII of 1934.

anchor.surface_text: the whole decree companyld be executed. Finally the decree created a charge on 1 8 villages belonging to the appellant. It may be added that the charge was created under s. 3 of the U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act, No. XXVII of 1934. The appellant paid the first 17 instalments in time.

facts.text: Appellant paid the first 17 instalments in time.

anchor.surface_text: No. XXVII of 1934. The appellant paid the first 17 instalments in time. He paid the eighteenth instalment on July 31, 1948 but this was late as by then the 20th instalment had also fallen due.

facts.text: Appellant paid the eighteenth instalment on July 31, 1948 but it was late as the 20th instalment had also fallen due.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant paid the first 17 instalments in time. He paid the eighteenth instalment on July 31, 1948 but this was late as by then the 20th instalment had also fallen due. As the 19th and 20th instalments as well as pendente lite and future interest had number been paid the decree was put in execution

facts.text: 19th and 20th instalments as well as pendente lite and future interest had not been paid.

anchor.surface_text: late as by then the 20th instalment had also fallen due. As the 19th and 20th instalments as well as pendente lite and future interest had number been paid the decree was put in execution by the respondents on April 26, 1951 for recovery of Rs. 49,000/- and odd by the sale of a kothi and an Ahata belonging to the appellant.

facts.text: Decree put in execution by respondents on April 26, 1951 for Rs. 49,000/- and odd by sale of a kothi and an Ahata.

anchor.surface_text: had number been paid the decree was put in execution by the respondents on April 26, 1951 for recovery of Rs. 49,000/- and odd by the sale of a kothi and an Ahata belonging to the appellant. The decree- holder respondent also prayed that in case the whole amount was numberrealised from the sale of the above property, zamidari property on which a charge bad been created might be put to sale.

facts.text: Decree-holder prayed for sale of zamindari property if amount not realised from kothi and ahata.

anchor.surface_text: by the sale of a kothi and an Ahata belonging to the appellant. The decree- holder respondent also prayed that in case the whole amount was numberrealised from the sale of the above property, zamidari property on which a charge bad been created might be put to sale.

facts.text: Appellant raised objections under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure against execution.

anchor.surface_text: zamidari property on which a charge bad been created might be put to sale. The appellant raised objections under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure against the execution. He also filed an application under ss. 4 and 8 of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, No. XV of 1963,

facts.text: Appellant filed application under ss. 4 and 8 of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, No. XV of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: against the execution. He also filed an application under ss. 4 and 8 of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, No. XV of 1963,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . It is unnecessary to refer to the objections in detail, for in the present appeals we are companycerned only with one point, namely, whether s. 4 of the Act applies to the present case.

facts.text: First court held that s. 4 of the Act did not apply and dismissed application under s. 4 and objection under s. 47.

anchor.surface_text: namely, whether s. 4 of the Act applies to the present case. Under that section the appellant had applied to the companyrt which passed the decree to reduce the amount as provided therein. Further in his objection under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure the appellant claimed the same relief. ... The first companyrt held that s. 4 of the Act did number apply.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal against dismissal of objection under s. 47 (Execution First Appeal No. 440 of 1953).

anchor.surface_text: It therefore dismissed both the application Linder s. 4 as well as the objection Linder s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure. ... This gave rise to two proceedings before the High Court. The appellant went in appeal against the dismissal of his objection under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Appellant filed civil revision against dismissal of application under s. 4 (Civil Revision No. 1402 of 1953).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went in appeal against the dismissal of his objection under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure. He also filed a civil revision against the dismissal of his application under s. 4 of the Act.

facts.text: High Court held that s. 4 did not apply and amount could not be reduced.

anchor.surface_text: The two matters were heard together by the High Court, which held that s. 4 did number apply and therefore the amount companyld number be reduced. The High Court having refused to grant leave to the appellant, he secured special leave from this Court

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant leave to the appellant, he secured special leave from this Court and that is how the matter arises before us. The Act was passed in 1953 to give relief to zamindars whose lands had been acquired

facts.text: U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act passed in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: that is how the matter arises before us. The Act was passed in 1953 to give relief to zamindars whose lands had been acquired by the State under the U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, No. 1 of 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in the view it took that this case was number companyered by s. 4 of the Act. The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed with companyts--one hearing fee.

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 24, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 440 of 1953 and Civil Revision No. 1402 of 1953. B. Agarwala and K. P. Gupta, for the appellant  in both the appeals .

The High Court having refused to grant leave to the appellant, he secured special leave from this Court and that is how the matter arises before us. The Act was passed in 1953 to give relief to zamindars whose lands had been acquired

zamidari property on which a charge bad been created might be put to sale. The appellant raised objections under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure against the execution. He also filed an application under ss. 4 and 8 of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, No. XV of 1963,

namely, whether s. 4 of the Act applies to the present case. Under that section the appellant had applied to the court which passed the decree to reduce the amount as provided therein. Further in his objection under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure the appellant claimed the same relief.

anchor.surface_text: The question that has been posed before us is the meaning of the words a decree relating to a secured debt. The comparable words in S. 3 Are a suit relating to a secured debt. As we have already said, so far as S. 3 is concerned it is the date on which the suit is filed which has to be seen to determine whether the suit relates to a secured debt as defined in the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Case not covered by s.4 as debt unsecured on suit date

holdings.text: Section 4 of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act does not apply to the present case as the decree does not relate to a secured debt.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in the view it took that this case was number companyered by s. 4 of the Act. The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed with companyts--one hearing fee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The underlying debt was unsecured on the date of suit based on promissory note; charge created by decree under U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act does not convert it to secured debt for purposes of s.4.

holdings.text: A 'decree relating to a secured debt' under s.4 means a decree passed in a suit based on a debt that was secured on the date of filing of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On the same reasoning when s. 4 speaks of a decree relating to a secured debt it means a decree passed in a suit which was based on a secured debt as on the date of the suit. The legislature companyld number have intended by using these words in s. 4 that the fact that the decree created a charge should result in companyverting what was an unsecured debt into a secured. debt for the purpose of s. 4.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words parallel 'suit relating to a secured debt' in s.3; same material words require consistent interpretation via harmonious construction; legislature would have used different words if intending to include decrees creating charges.

holdings.text: The relevant date to determine whether a debt is secured for ss.3 and 4 of the Act is the date on which the suit is filed.

anchor.surface_text: The date therefore on which the companyrt has to see whether the debt in the suit before it is a secured debt or number is the date on which the suit is filed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For s.3, mortgage or charge must exist on date of suit; same applies to s.4 by analogy as words are identical; post-suit creation of charge by decree irrelevant.

holdings.text: 'Secured debt' under the Act includes a debt secured by a charge as defined in s.100 of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to have overlooked that part of the definition of the word mortgage which lays down that a mortgage will include a charge as defined in s. 100 of the Transfer of Property Act. Therefore, even though a debt may be secured by a charge it will be a secured debt for the purpose of s. 3 provided the charge was there before the date of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual definition in s.2: mortgage includes charge per TPA s.100; High Court erred in excluding charges.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed with companyts--one hearing fee.
